Name: Acretin
Uses: Treatment of acne vulgaris, hyperpigmentation and fine wrinkling of photodamaged skin, and acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL)​
Side Effects: Primary irritant dermatitis, irritation, erythema, peeling, sensation of warmth, slight stinging​

Name: Adol
Uses: Management of mild to moderate pain, fever, treatment for various conditions including arthritis, cold, cough, muscle pain​
Side Effects: Pain and burning sensation at injection site, hypersensitivity reactions, skin rash, urticaria, anaphylactic shock

Name: Aggrex
Uses: Primarily for the prevention of myocardial infarction and ischemic stroke, and for treating mild to moderate pain, fever, and various inflammatory conditions
Side Effects: May cause gastric disturbances and increased bleeding tendency, especially in susceptible individuals

Name: Airoplast
Uses: Dressing retention; suitable for patients sensitive to traditional tapes.
Side Effects: Generally well tolerated; hypoallergenic.

Name: All-Vent
GENERIC NAME(S): Bromhexine hydrochloride, Terbutaline sulphate, Guaifenesin, Menthol
Uses: Treatment of productive cough associated with bronchospasm in bronchitis, bronchial asthma, COPD, bronchiectasis, emphysema​
Side Effects: Tremor, nervousness, increased heart rate, palpitations, dizziness, headache, drowsiness, vomiting, nausea, sweating, muscle cramps​

Name: Alphintern
Uses: Anti-inflammatory and anti-edematous; used for the reduction and resorption of edema and exudates, adjunctive therapy in inflammatory conditions
Side Effects: Bloating, flatulence, change of stool texture, color, and smell; occasional reports of asthma and rare allergic reactions​

Name: Ambezim-G
Uses: Digestive enzyme supplement used in supportive therapy for side effects of chemotherapy, radiotherapy, hormone therapy, and various inflammatory conditions​

Name: Amrizole
Uses: an antibiotic used to treat various bacterial and protozoal infections. It is often used to treat infections of the gastrointestinal tract, skin, and reproductive system.
Side Effects: Common side effects may include nausea, diarrhea, metallic taste in the mouth, and dizziness.
Dosage Limit: The dosage limit for metronidazole can vary depending on the specific condition being treated and the prescribing physician's instructions. It is typically taken as directed by a healthcare professional.

Name: Antopral
Uses: Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor used to reduce stomach acid production. It is commonly prescribed to treat conditions such as gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), peptic ulcers, and Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.
Side Effects: Common side effects may include headache, nausea, diarrhea, and abdominal pain.
Dosage Limit: The dosage limit for omeprazole can vary depending on the specific condition and should be determined by a healthcare professional.

Name: Asmakast
Uses: Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist used to manage and prevent asthma symptoms and relieve seasonal allergies.
Side Effects: Common side effects may include headache, stomach pain, and fatigue.
Dosage Limit: The dosage limit for montelukast can vary depending on the age and condition of the patient and should be determined by a healthcare professional.

Name: Atoreza
Uses: Atoreza is a combination medication used to lower cholesterol levels in the blood. It is prescribed to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.
Side Effects: Common side effects may include muscle pain, weakness, and gastrointestinal symptoms.
Dosage Limit: The dosage limit for Atoreza can vary depending on the patient's specific cholesterol levels and cardiovascular risk factors. It should be determined by a healthcare professional.

Name: Augmentin
Uses: Antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections such as respiratory tract infections, urinary tract infections, skin infections, and ear infections.
Side Effects: Common side effects include nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, and rash. Allergic reactions, including severe reactions such as anaphylaxis, are rare but possible.
Dosage Limit: Dosage typically depends on the severity of the infection and the patient's age and weight. Common dosages range from 250 mg/125 mg to 875 mg/125 mg taken orally every 8 or 12 hours.

Name: Betaderm
Uses: Corticosteroid cream or ointment used to reduce inflammation, itching, redness, and swelling associated with various skin conditions like eczema, dermatitis, and psoriasis.
Side Effects: Side effects may include thinning of the skin, irritation, burning or itching sensation, acne, stretch marks, increased hair growth, and contact dermatitis.
Dosage Limit: The dosage and duration of treatment depend on the specific condition being treated, the severity of symptoms, and the patient's response. It is usually applied thinly to the affected area once or twice daily.

Name: Betadine
Uses: Antiseptic solution used to clean and disinfect wounds, cuts, and burns. Also used as a pre-operative skin cleanser.
Side Effects: May cause skin irritation or allergic reaction. Prolonged use can lead to iodine absorption and thyroid problems. Systemic allergic reactions are rare but possible, especially with extensive burns or deep wounds.
Dosage Limit: For topical use, the solution is typically applied to the affected area once or twice daily, as directed by a healthcare professional.

Name: Bivatracin
Uses: Antibiotic ointment used to prevent and treat minor skin infections caused by bacteria.
Side Effects: Possible side effects include skin irritation or allergic reaction. Systemic allergic reactions are rare but possible, particularly if absorbed through broken skin in large amounts.
Dosage Limit: Bacitracin is usually applied to the affected area 1 to 3 times daily, as directed by a healthcare professional.

Name: Bronchicum Elixir
Uses: Herbal cough syrup used to relieve cough and soothe the throat.

Name: Brufen
Uses: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used to relieve pain, reduce inflammation, and lower fever associated with conditions such as headache, toothache, menstrual cramps, muscle aches, and arthritis.
Dosage Limit: The recommended dosage for adults is typically 200 mg to 800 mg every 4 to 6 hours as needed for pain relief or fever reduction. The maximum daily dose should not exceed 3200 mg.

Name: C Zinc
Uses: Zinc supplement; specific uses not provided.

Name: Carbamide
Uses: Topical medication used to moisturize and soften dry, rough, or scaly skin.

Name: Cataflam
Uses: NSAID used to relieve pain, reduce inflammation, and lower fever associated with conditions such as arthritis, menstrual cramps, and mild to moderate pain.
Side Effects: Potential side effects include stomach upset, heartburn, nausea, headache, dizziness, and rash. Long-term or high-dose use may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, ulcers, and cardiovascular events.
Dosage Limit: The recommended dosage for adults is typically 50 mg to 150 mg per day, divided into 2 or 3 doses. The maximum daily dose should not exceed 150 mg.

Name: Ceftriaxone
Uses: Antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections such as pneumonia, meningitis, gonorrhea, and intra-abdominal infections.
Side Effects: Side effects may include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, rash, and allergic reactions, including severe reactions like anaphylaxis. Pseudomembranous colitis, a severe form of diarrhea, is also possible.
Dosage Limit: Dosage depends on the type and severity of the infection, as well as the patient's age and weight. It is usually administered intravenously or intramuscularly once or twice daily.

Name: Celebrex
Uses: NSAID used to relieve pain, inflammation, and stiffness caused by arthritis, osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and ankylosing spondylitis.
Side Effects: Possible side effects include stomach upset, heartburn, nausea, diarrhea, headache, dizziness, and rash. Long-term use or use in individuals with pre-existing heart conditions may increase the risk of cardiovascular events.
Dosage Limit: The usual recommended dosage for osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis is 100 mg to 200 mg taken orally once or twice daily. The maximum daily dose should not exceed 400 mg.

Name: Cetal
Uses: Antihistamine used to relieve symptoms of allergic rhinitis (hay fever) such as sneezing, runny nose, itching, and watery eyes.

Name: Cetal Sinus
Uses: Likely similar to Cetal but formulated specifically for sinus relief.

Name: Ciprodiazole
GENERIC NAME(S):
Ciprofloxacin: Fluoroquinolone antibiotic.
Metronidazole: Antibiotic, antiprotozoal.
Uses: Treats urinary tract, respiratory tract, skin, and gastrointestinal infections, Used for bacterial vaginosis, pelvic inflammatory disease, amoebiasis, giardiasis, trichomoniasis, and certain abdominal, skin, and joint infections.
Side Effects: Nausea, diarrhea, dizziness, headache, sunlight sensitivity. Rare: tendon rupture, QT prolongation, vomiting, dry mouth, metallic taste.
Dosage Limit:
Varies based on the infection being treated.
For example, for trichomoniasis: 2 grams taken once or 500 mg twice daily for 7 days.

Name: Ciprofar
Uses: Treating bacterial infections such as urinary tract infections, respiratory tract.
Side Effects: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, Headache, dizziness, Photosensitivity.
Dosage Limit: Adult: 250-500 mg every 12 hours for 7-14 days (mild to moderate), 500-750 mg.

Name: Ciprofloxacin Tablets USP 39
Uses: Treat bacterial infections (e.g., urinary tract infections, respiratory infections)
Side Effects: Nausea, Diarrhea, Dizziness, Headache, Photosensitivity, Rash, Rare serious effects: Tendon rupture, Nervous system effects, Hypersensitivity
Dosage Limit: Typical adult dose: 250-750 mg every 12 hours (Duration depends on infection type)

Name: Clarinase
Uses: Relief of allergic rhinitis symptoms, sinus congestion and pressure
Side Effects: Drowsiness, Headache, Dry mouth, Dizziness, Nausea, Difficulty sleeping, Increased heart rate
Dosage Limit: Adults and children >12 years: 1 tablet (loratadine 5 mg and pseudoephedrine 120 mg) twice a day.

Name: Claritine
Uses:
Relief from allergy symptoms, such as sneezing, runny nose, itchy/watery eyes, and itchy throat/nose,
Treatment of chronic urticaria (hives).
Side Effects:
Headache
Drowsiness
Fatigue
Dry mouth
Gastrointestinal disturbances (e.g., gastritis, nausea)
In rare cases, severe allergic reactions.
Dosage Limit:
Adults and Children 6 Years and Older: 10 mg once daily.
Children 2 to 5 Years: 5 mg once daily (syrup or orally disintegrating tablets).

Name: Clindasol
Uses:
Treating bacterial infections, particularly those of the skin, lungs, internal organs, and female reproductive organs.
Sometimes used for treating acne and certain types of bone infections.
Side Effects:
Severe diarrhea or diarrhea that doesn't go away
Yellowing of the skin or eyes (jaundice)
Severe allergic reactions (difficulty breathing, swelling of face or throat)
Blood/mucus in stool,
Vaginal itching or discharge
Dosage Limit:
Common adult oral dosage: 150-450 mg every 6-8 hours
Dosage for children: Based on body weight, usually 8-20 mg/kg/day divided into 3-4 doses
Maximum daily dosage for severe infections: Up to 1800-2700 mg in divided doses

Name: Comfort Massage Gel
Uses: Muscle pain relief, Joint stiffness, Arthritis pain, Back pain, Sprains, Strains
Side Effects: Skin irritation, Redness, Allergic reactions, Mild itching, Dry skin, Rash
Dosage Limit: Not more than 4 times a day

Name: Congestal
Uses:
Relief of symptoms associated with the common cold, flu, and allergies
Reducing fever,
Alleviating pain,
Relieving nasal congestion
Side Effects:
Drowsiness,
Dizziness,
Nausea,
Vomiting,
Dry mouth,
Difficulty sleeping,
Increased blood pressure,
Rapid heart rate
Dosage Limit: Max 4 tablets in 24 hrs, Not for children < 12 yrs

Name: Conta-flu
Uses: Relief from symptoms of the common cold, flu, or allergies, including fever, aches, nasal congestion, and sneezing.
Side Effects: Can include dizziness, drowsiness, dry mouth/nose/throat, headache, nausea, and nervousness.
Dosage Limit: For adults, it's often recommended not to exceed 4 doses in 24 hours.

Name: Corasore
GENERIC NAME(S):
Corasolium Hydrochloride (Corasol HCl)
Corasorenate Sodium (Corasoren Na)
Uses:
Treatment of moderate to severe chronic pain,
Management of post-surgical pain,
Relief from neuropathic pain in adults
Side Effects:
Respiratory depression,
Severe hypotension,
Allergic reactions (rash, itching, swelling)
and Seizures
Dosage Limit: Adult: 10-40 mg/4-6 hrs, max 120 mg/24 hrs; Elderly: Max 60 mg/24 hrs; Pediatric: Not recommended

Name: C-Retard
Uses: Immune support, Antioxidant, Collagen synthesis, etc.
Side Effects: Stomach upset, Kidney stones, etc. (at high doses)
Dosage Limit: recommended dietary allowance

Name: C-vit
Uses: Boosts the immune system, antioxidant, prevents and treats scurvy, aids in the absorption of iron, used as a dietary supplement.
Side Effects: Nausea, vomiting, heartburn, stomach cramps, headache, others.
Dosage Limit:
Adult Daily Recommended Amount: 65-90 mg,
Maximum Daily Dose: 2000 mg

Name: Daflon
Uses:
Treatment of chronic venous disease (CVD)
Symptomatic treatment of hemorrhoidal disease
Management of symptoms related to acute hemorrhoidal attacks
Side Effects:
Common: Gastrointestinal disturbances (like diarrhea, dyspepsia, nausea), headache
Rare: Colitis, dizziness, malaise, rash, pruritus, urticaria
Dosage Limit:
For Chronic Venous Disease: Standard dose is 1,000 mg per day.
For Acute Hemorrhoidal Attacks: Initial dose of 3,000 mg per day for the first 4 days, then 2,000 mg per day for the next 3 days.
For Hemorrhoidal Disease: Typically, 500 mg twice daily.

Name: Daktarin
Uses: Treatment of fungal skin infections such as athlete's foot, jock itch, ringworm; Treatment of certain yeast infections; Relief from symptoms such as itching, burning, and redness associated with fungal infections
Side Effects: Burning, stinging, or redness at the application site; Allergic reactions like rash, itching, swelling (especially of the face, tongue, throat); Severe dizziness; Trouble breathing
Dosage Limit: Cream/Gel: Apply a small amount to the affected area once or twice daily (usually for 2 to 6 weeks); Powder: Apply to the affected area once or twice daily; Oral Gel: Apply to the affected area in the mouth 2-4 times a day; Duration varies with type and severity of infection

Name: Dalacin C
Uses: treats various bacterial infections, including skin infections, respiratory tract infections, bone and joint infections, and more.
Side Effects: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, skin rash.
Dosage Limit: depending on the type and severity of the infection.

Name: Davalindi
Uses: Treatment of severe skin infections caused by bacteria
Side Effects: Allergic reactions (hives, difficulty breathing, swelling), severe stomach pain, watery or bloody diarrhea
Dosage Limit: Adults: 1500 mg IV once or 1000 mg followed by 500 mg after a week. Children: 22.5 mg/kg for children under 6 years, 18 mg/kg for 6-18 years, maximum 1500 mg/dose

Name: Dentinox
Uses: Relief of discomfort in infants due to colic, gas, and trapped wind
Side Effects: Rarely causes side effects, but can include skin rash, itching, and difficulty breathing (allergic reaction)
Dosage Limit: 40-125 mg or 1-3 chewable tablets, 4 times daily, up to 500 mg/day,

Name: Diclac
Uses:
Pain relief (e.g., headaches, dental pain, muscle pain),
 Reducing inflammation,
 Treating menstrual pain,
 Managing symptoms of osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and ankylosing spondylitis
Side Effects:
Gastrointestinal problems (e.g., nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation),
 Dizziness, headache,
 Elevated blood pressure,
Liver function abnormalities,
 Allergic reactions (rare),
 Increased risk of cardiovascular events (e.g., heart attack, stroke) in long-term or high-dose usage
Dosage Limit: Typically 50 mg 2-3 times a day. Maximum: 150 mg/day.

Name: Diclac 75 ID
Uses:
Pain relief (e.g., dental pain, menstrual cramps, muscle aches),
Treatment of arthritis (e.g., osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis),
 To reduce inflammation and swelling
Side Effects:
Nausea and vomiting,
Diarrhea or constipation,
 Headache, dizziness,
Drowsiness, tiredness,
 Elevated blood pressure,
Stomach pain, heartburn, gas,
Serious side effects: gastrointestinal bleeding, liver damage, heart attack, stroke, severe allergic reactions
Dosage Limit:
The typical dose for Diclac 75 ID (Diclofenac 75 mg) is usually taken once or twice daily.
The maximum daily dose should not exceed 150 mg.

Name: Diflucan
Uses: Treatment of fungal infections like yeast infections of the vagina, mouth, throat, esophagus, abdomen, lungs, blood, and other organs. Preventive treatment for fungal infections in people with a weak immune system, such as those with cancer, HIV/AIDS, and organ transplant recipients. Treatment of meningitis caused by fungi.
Side Effects:
Headache, dizziness,
Stomach pain, diarrhea,
Changes in taste,
Nausea, vomiting,
Severe skin reactions (rare),
Liver problems (rare but serious),
Changes in blood counts
Dosage Limit:
For vaginal yeast infections, a single dose of 150 mg is common.
For other infections, doses can range from 50 mg to 400 mg per day

Name: Ectomethrin
Uses: Used topically to treat scabies and lice infestations.
Side Effects: Skin irritation or burning sensation at the application site

Name: Ezamol-C

Name: Fenistil

Name: Picolax
Uses: a bowel preparation medication used to cleanse the colon before certain diagnostic procedures

Name: Predsol

Name: Pridocaine

Name: Primrose Plus

Name: Rennie

Name: Reparil-Gel N

Name: Sediproct

Name: SelokenZOC

Name: Steronate
